comment.author: 23061408@N04
comment._content: If you look at enough of these you notice that not only are they beautifully composed and lit, they often make use of a single area of bright color, usually the woman's clothes. While these may well be the real women from the factory, these are NOT their work clothes! The pictures are posed. This one is even wearing makeup -- unlikely on a factory floor on wartime; it would probably have been considered in bad taste, in fact. But appropriate for a photo shoot.

comment.author: 99383977@N00
comment._content: I was an aircraft maven during the war; had a book of warplane profiles so I could identify any Japanese craft that might fly over Hancock, NH, aiming to bomb the grange hall. It was intended to help air raid wardens identify planes they might see, including our own, and I'm quite convinced there's a minor error in the caption here: the B-17 was an Army Air Corps craft. It couldn't possibly have flown off a carrier deck in those days.

comment.author: 8125586@N08
comment._content: Good call Graycard. However, it should be noted that just because an aircraft couldn't fly off of a carrier deck doesn't mean it couldn't have been a Navy aircraft. This one, however, was regardless not a Navy aircraft.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Ironically, Plexiglas is a German invention, developed by Rohm & Haas ('das Glas' is German for 'glass') in the 1930s. Their American branch did very well during the war. You can read the company history at their web site.

comment.author: 38814402@N00
comment._content:
Nice promotional photo. I must agree with Erenst Adams. Definately staged.  Check out the jewelry. Not something to be worn while working with this assembly. No sense in scratching it before it leaves the plant.
The Navy and the Coast Guard did fly a variant of the B-17

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Good point, Paul! I think the wedding ring is there for a reason. The photo was used in a recruiting poster, probably targeting idle married women (most single women being already employed). You can find the poster under "Rosie Pictures: Select Images Relating to American Women Workers During World War II" at the LOC web site. Note how the ID badge has been changed from "Zone 3 Temporary 3007" to "Zone X Temporary 0000." (subliminal kiss and hugs?)

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
Here's another pic of temp worker #3007 posing with a different kind of plane in El Segundo! It's the same woman. Same badge, watch, clothing and snood. Way less make-up, though. Very interesting!

comment.author: 16944380@N08
comment._content:
The Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress is a four-engine heavy bomber aircraft developed for the United States Army Air Corps (USAAC), introduced in the 1930s. Competing against Douglas and Martin for a contract to build 200 bombers, the Boeing entry outperformed both competitors and more than met the Air Corps' expectations. Although Boeing lost the contract due to the prototype's crash, the Air Corps was so impressed with Boeing's design that they ordered 13 B-17s. The B-17 Flying Fortress went on to eventually evolve through numerous design advancements.

The B-17 was primarily employed by the United States Army Air Forces (USAAF) in the daylight precision strategic bombing campaign of World War II against German industrial, civilian, and military targets. The United States Eighth Air Force based in England and the Fifteenth Air Force based in Italy complemented the RAF Bomber Command's nighttime area bombing in Operation Pointblank, to help secure air superiority over the cities, factories and battlefields of Western Europe in preparation for Operation Overlord.[4] The B-17 also participated, to a lesser extent, in the War in the Pacific, where it conducted raids against Japanese shipping and airfields.
